title: 114_hr4408
content: The Act titled "National Strategy to Combat Terrorist Travel Act of 2016" aims to combat terrorist travel. The Act emphasizes the need for the US to regularly assess terrorist threats, catalog existing efforts to obstruct terrorist travel, identify security vulnerabilities, and prioritize resources to address them. The President is required to transmit updates on the national strategy to combat terrorist travel to Congress. The President must submit a national strategy to combat terrorist travel to Congress, addressing efforts to intercept terrorists and foreign fighters. The strategy should be submitted in unclassified form within 180 days of the enactment of the Act, with updates to follow. The President must submit a national strategy to combat terrorist travel to Congress within 180 days of a new administration. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop the strategy and coordinate with other federal agencies. The strategy will include details of government programs to restrict terrorist and foreign fighter travel. The national strategy to combat terrorist travel must identify security vulnerabilities and goals for closing them, as well as actions to enhance the government's ability to constrain travel by terrorists and foreign fighters. Steps to reform existing efforts will also be outlined. The national strategy to combat terrorist travel aims to streamline Federal Government efforts to align with the current threat environment, implement new programs, request new authorities from Congress, propose budget adjustments for enhanced security, and identify responsible departments and agencies. The requirement to transmit updated national strategies under this subsection will end 7 years after the enactment of the Act. The President will direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop implementation plans for each national strategy and coordinate with other relevant Federal agencies. Implementation plans for each national strategy will be transmitted to congressional committees in unclassified form. The implementation plans for national strategies must be transmitted in unclassified form, with the possibility of a classified annex. These plans will be updated annually and sent to congressional committees. The requirement to transmit these plans will end 10 years after the enactment of the Act. No additional funds are authorized for this section. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives. The committees involved in overseeing national strategies implementation include the Committee on Homeland Security, Armed Services, Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, Judiciary, Foreign Affairs, and Appropriations in the House of Representatives, and similar committees in the Senate. The House of Representatives passed the bill on February 23, 2016, as confirmed by Clerk Karen L. Haas.
